item.title: How Europe Is Moving to Reduce Dependence on Trump
item.description: Since President Trump made threats about Greenland, the continent’s leaders have debated the rapid deterioration of U.S. ties in policy papers and at dinner.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Lara Jakes, Steven Erlanger and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Ronny Hartmann/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: European leaders on Monday at a summit in Hamburg, Germany. Although they are verbally pushing harder than ever against President Trump, they are still struggling to bolster their statements with action.

item.title: U.S. Allies Are Drawing Closer to China, but on Beijing’s Terms
item.description: As Washington unsettles its partners, Beijing is reaping diplomatic gains, without backing down on human rights, trade or security.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Berry Wang
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kin Cheung
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain in Shanghai on Friday. Mr. Starmer became the first British leader to visit China since 2018.

item.title: ICE Expands Power of Agents to Arrest People Without Warrants
item.description: An internal memo changed the standard from whether people are unlikely to show up for hearings to whether they could leave the scene.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents attempted to raid a home in Minneapolis earlier this week.

item.title: Trump Called for ‘De-Escalation’ in Minneapolis. It Didn’t Last Long.
item.description: President Trump has offered dueling messages on the crisis in Minneapolis, part of a pattern of dialing back his rhetoric only to change again if the political winds are shifting.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: Release of Three Million Epstein Pages Falls Short, Survivors Say
item.description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, told reporters on Friday that “there’s a hunger or a thirst for information that I do not think will be satisfied by the review of these documents.”
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Michael Gold and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: J. Scott Applewhite/Associated Press
item.media:description: Todd Blanche, the deputy attorney general, addressed reporters after the Justice Department released more Epstein files.

item.title: Draft Epstein Indictment Accused Him of Crimes Against More Than a Dozen Girls
item.description: Jeffrey Epstein, who ended up pleading to a much lesser state charge, told one victim that bad things could happen to her if she talked, the 2007 document said.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2019, the F.B.I. announced new sex trafficking charges against Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier.

item.title: Here’s What to Know About the Millions of Pages of Epstein Documents
item.description: Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche signaled that this would be the last major release of files related to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Jon Elswick/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Justice Department released millions of new pages related to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Trump’s Lawsuit Against I.R.S. Creates ‘Enormous Conflict of Interest’
item.description: The president is demanding that the federal government pay him at least $10 billion over the unauthorized disclosure of his tax returns during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump created what legal experts called an unparalleled situation of federal agencies facing a lawsuit from the head of the executive branch.

item.title: Trump Picks Kevin Warsh as Next Fed Chair
item.description: If confirmed by the Senate, Kevin M. Warsh, a former governor at the central bank, will replace Jerome H. Powell, whose term as chair ends in May.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith, Tony Romm and Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Kevin M. Warsh, a former Federal Reserve governor, was also a front-runner to lead the central bank during President Trump’s first term.

item.title: Trump Officials Bypass Congress to Push Billions in Weapons Aid to Israel
item.description: The move was the third time the Trump administration has tried to expedite arms shipments to Israel by going around the review process for weapons sales.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Gonzalo Fuentes/Reuters
item.media:description: The weapons aid included Apache attack helicopters and combat land vehicles.

item.title: Kevin Warsh, Trump’s Choice for Fed Chair Could Find It Difficult to Deliver
item.description: Kevin M. Warsh, whom Mr. Trump tapped to become the next chair of the Federal Reserve, could face fierce resistance if he tries to pursue substantially lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Catherine O’Hara, ‘Home Alone’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Actress, Dies at 71
item.description: An Emmy-winning comedian with oddball charm, she got her start with the influential Canadian sketch comedy series “SCTV.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019.

item.title: Macaulay Culkin And Others Pay Tribute to Catherine O’Hara After Her Death
item.description: Videos and photos filled social media as fans shared their favorite scenes from O’Hara’s acting career and co-stars memorialized her.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Danny Moloshok/Reuters
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara in 2019. The actress died this week at the age of 71.

item.title: Where to Watch Catherine O’Hara’s Best Performances, From ‘Beetlejuice’ to ‘Best in Show’
item.description: Her characters were as varied as they were eccentric and lovable. These are some of the best.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Pop TV
item.media:description: Catherine O’Hara won a best lead actress Emmy for her role as the down-and-out former millionaire Moira Rose in the sitcom “Schitt’s Creek.”

item.title: Death Toll During New York City Cold Snap Rises to 13
item.description: The growing number of deaths comes amid heightened concern about Mayor Zohran Mamdani’s handling of last weekend’s winter storm and the aftermath.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri and Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Junction playground in Queens where the body of one victim was found.

item.title: Winter Storm to Hit Carolinas With Snow, Winds and Freezing Cold
item.description: Southern towns more used to hurricane preparation than snowstorms may experience some of their highest snow totals in years.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina, Emily Cochrane and Judson Jones
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Could the Hudson River Freeze Over?
item.description: New York City is icy and cold right now, but you’re probably not going to be able to walk to New Jersey any time soon.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff and Joel Eastwood
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ice floating in the New York Bay from the East and Hudson Rivers continues to affect ferry operations in Downtown Manhattan.

item.title: Iran Rules Out Talks With U.S. Until Trump’s Threats Stop
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister ruled out direct talks unless President Trump stops threatening to attack it. He also said Iran would not discuss its ballistic missiles.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Burak Kara/Getty Images
item.media:description: “Just as we are ready for negotiations, we are ready for warfare,” Abbas Araghchi, the foreign minister of Iran, left, said on Friday in Istanbul alongside his Turkish counterpart, Hakan Fidan.

item.title: Why Trump Is Going After Iran Now
item.description: As President Trump warns that “we have a lot of very big, very powerful ships sailing to Iran right now,” our national security correspondent David E. Sanger breaks down what to know.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Coleman Lowndes, Valentina Caval, Nikolay Nikolov and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: Children Were Arrested in Iran’s Brutal Crackdown on Protests
item.description: An Iranian government official said some children had been detained, the first such acknowledgment in weeks of anti-government protests.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at Tehran University in 2024. Students, particularly at universities, have long been at the forefront of struggles for democratic change in Iran.

item.title: ‘Melania’ Review: 20 Stage-Managed Days in the Life of the First Lady
item.description: Directed by Brett Ratner, the documentary shows a woman deeply concerned with her appearance who rarely lets us behind her facade.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: 6 Takeaways from ‘Melania,’ the Melania Trump Documentary
item.description: The film, which counts Melania Trump as a producer, touches on her immigrant roots, her love for her mother and her style, but there are few revelations.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: ‘Heated Rivalry’ Fans Want the Fleece. They’ll Be Able to Get It.
item.description: American and Canadian “Heated Rivalry” fans are hot for the jacket worn by the character Shane Hollander.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: The Secret Sauce in ‘Heated Rivalry’? Canada.
item.description: The global television phenomenon is full of Canadian iconography and subsidized by Canadian taxpayers. On Thursday, it came home to celebrate.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Cole Burston
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Heated Rivalry actor Hudson Williams on the red carpet at a conference for the Canadian Media Producers Association in Ottawa on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. Says It’s in Danger of Financial Collapse Because of Members’ Unpaid Dues
item.description: The world body warned it would run out of money by July and have to close its New York headquarters if countries, namely the United States, did not pay annual dues that amount to billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Assembly in September. The U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, sent a letter to the ambassadors of all 196 member states on Thursday saying, “I cannot overstate the urgency of the situation we now face.”

item.title: Grand Jury Hears Evidence on Brooklyn Power Broker
item.description: Brooklyn federal prosecutors have been conducting a corruption investigation into Frank Carone, who served as Mayor Eric Adams’s chief of staff.
item.dc:creator: William K. Rashbaum and Dana Rubinstein
item.category: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Frank Carone has been under federal investigation since 2024, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

item.title: Loss, Grief and a World Record Attempt at 81
item.description: Facing life on her own for the first time in 60 years, Bonnie Sumner discovered she had a special skill for hanging from a pull-up bar.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Achauer
item.media:credit: Chet Strange for The New York Times

item.title: A Farewell Column From David Brooks
item.description: After 22 wonderful years, I’ve decided to take the exciting and terrifying step of leaving in order to try to build something new.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Chris Maggio for The New York Times

item.title: Young People Are Using A.I. to Skip the Hardest Part of Growing Up
item.description: Artificial intelligence is replacing young people's social intuitions.
item.dc:creator: Clay Shirky

item.title: Texas A&M Ends Women’s Studies and Overhauls Hundreds of Classes on Race and Gender
item.description: New policies limiting the teaching of race and gender issues led administrators and professors to change hundreds of courses. School leaders say the rules could hurt A&M’s reputation.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texas A&M University’s new policy to limit teaching about race and gender has led to debates on campus about academic freedom.

item.title: Federal Judge Drops Death Penalty Charge Against Luigi Mangione
item.description: Judge Margaret Garnett of Federal District Court dismissed two charges against Luigi Mangione, including one that carried the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko, Benjamin Weiser and Anusha Bayya
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times

item.title: Decades Later, a Man’s Conviction Is Overturned With Ex-Inmate’s Help
item.description: On Friday, a Queens judge vacated the double-murder conviction of Allen Porter. Jabbar Collins, who was exonerated 16 years ago, never stopped fighting for the friend he met in custody.
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allen Porter, right, embraces Jabbar Collins after being released from prison on Friday night and being reunited with his family and friends.

item.title: Escape to Alcatraz: Coyote Swims a Mile in Search of New Turf
item.description: The coyote struggled onto the rocky shore this month. It is the first documented coyote on Alcatraz since the island was transferred to the National Park Service in 1972.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coyote swam ashore at Alcatraz Island this month. It is the first documented coyote presence there since the island was transferred to the National Park Service in 1972.
